transcription.text:
The video starts with a simple black background featuring a white clock. Then, it transitions to a lively scene of people swimming in the water. A capture follows of a woman and a child balancing on a log in the water. The footage then focuses on groups of people frolicking in the water, passing a beach ball around, demonstrating pure vacation fun. A woman and two children make a delightful appearance, engaged in aquatic play. The scene shifts to a solitary man on a boat in dim light, and then he is shown standing on the side of the boat. The video concludes with a serene shot of a woman and two children on a dock.

A man is seen sitting on a boat in darkness. The boat drifts gently on the water. Suddenly, the scene changes to a white clock on a black background.

Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family), examines her paternal family’s history of farming practices in rural Southern Malaysia. Footage of domestic-scale palm oil plantations in Bagan (Johor State) is interspersed with visual and auditory recordings of funerary Taoist rituals, documents and interviews that consider the palm oil industry and relevant history of migration in the local area.

“Just like in the arcade games of the past, the government initiatives that exist are currently about us, without us. I want us to be seen, to have a say that enables us to take back control.”

Jarra Karalinar Steel conjures the nostalgic excitement of 1990s videogame arcades in More Than Just a Game. At its centre is The Adventures of Dolly, a playable game made with Wiradjuri and Ngiyampaa illustrator Charlotte Allingham. Take the controls and take Dolly on a journey through an alternate reality or not-so-distant future of Melbourne’s CBD, featuring iconic trams and Swanston Street.Growing up, videogame protagonists weren’t relatable to Jarra.

This work remedies that, giving First Peoples a chance to see ourselves imagined in a videogame – made for us, by us. Through The Adventures of Dolly, custom possum and wallaby spirit flooring and the hand-carved arcade cabinet, Jarra reclaims a place that hasn’t reflected our experiences. She brings Indigenous stories into gaming, inspiring the next generation and giving us power to determine our own futures.
